clusters.title: Coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, US study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, US study finds: Trial’s findings go against common beliefs that people with atrial fibrillation should avoid caffeinated coffeeDrinking coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, despite the conventional wisdom to the contrary, according to a new study.The Does Eliminating Coffee Avoid Fibrillation (Decaf) clinical trial found 200 patients with persistent irregular heartbeats had a “significantly” lower risk of the condition recurring if they belonged to the study group that was allocated coffee consumption rather than the one abstaining from it – 47% to 64%. Continue reading

Continue reading...

ai_summary: A US study suggests coffee may protect against irregular heartbeats.
The study contradicts the belief that people with atrial fibrillation should avoid coffee.
The trial involved 200 patients with persistent irregular heartbeats.
Patients consuming coffee had a lower risk of the condition recurring.
The findings challenge conventional wisdom regarding coffee consumption.

clusters.title: As a palliative care specialist, I’ve witnessed the human tragedy of our end-of-life care crisis | Rachel Clarke
clusters.neutral_headline: As a palliative care specialist, I’ve witnessed the human tragedy of our end-of-life care crisis | Rachel Clarke: While the government debates assisted dying, palliative care is an afterthought. And many more people face death without the care and support they needA baby, in Britain, in 2025, takes its stuttering final breaths. All deaths in infancy are harrowing. But the fact that this particular death might have been prevented – had neonatal care not depended so heavily on charity, had the NHS not failed to fund more than two-thirds of the healthcare babies need – is unforgivable.Mercifully, the dystopian scenario I’ve just described does not exist in the UK today. Although paediatric care is undeniably overstretched, it is at least regarded as a core, bedrock NHS service.Dr Rachel Clarke is an NHS specialist in palliative medicine and the winner of the 2025 Women’s prize for nonfiction Continue reading

The author emphasizes the human tragedy of the current situation.

clusters.title: Waiting for the all-clear: how medics and villagers rallied when Ebola returned to DRC
clusters.neutral_headline: Waiting for the all-clear: how medics and villagers rallied when Ebola returned to DRC: If no new cases are reported in Bulape by early December, the country will have vanquished its 16th outbreak of the deadly virus since it was discovered there in 1976His two-year-old daughter died first, then his mother, then his wife. But Bope Mpona Héritier still had no idea what illness had taken their lives. Then the 25-year-old also began to develop symptoms. When his blood was tested and sent to the Democratic Republic of the Congo’s capital, Kinshasa, the results confirmed he had the Ebola virus.“I felt pain everywhere,” he says. “I had a migraine, a sharp pain in my eyes and throat, and I was vomiting. I couldn’t eat anything because I had no appetite, so I lost a lot of weight.” Continue reading

clusters.title: No link between paracetamol in pregnancy and autism or ADHD in children, review finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Paracetamol in pregnancy shows no autism or ADHD link

items.title: No link between paracetamol in pregnancy and autism or ADHD in children, review finds
items.standfirst: Wide-ranging review finds no convincing connection after Trump said women should ‘fight like hell’ to avoid painkillerA wide-ranging review into paracetamol use by pregnant women has found no convincing link between the common painkiller and the chances of children being diagnosed with autism and ADHD.Publication of the work was fast-tracked to provide prospective mothers and their doctors with reliable information after the Trump administration urged pregnant women to avoid paracetamol – also known as acetaminophen or Tylenol – claiming it was contributing to rising rates of autism. Continue reading...
items.content: Wide-ranging review finds no convincing connection after Trump said women should ‘fight like hell’ to avoid painkillerA wide-ranging review into paracetamol use by pregnant women has found no convincing link between the common painkiller and the chances of children being diagnosed with autism and ADHD.Publication of the work was fast-tracked to provide prospective mothers and their doctors with reliable information after the Trump administration urged pregnant women to avoid paracetamol – also known as acetaminophen or Tylenol – claiming it was contributing to rising rates of autism. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A review found no link between paracetamol use during pregnancy and autism or ADHD in children.
The review was expedited after the Trump administration's concerns about the painkiller's effects.
The administration urged pregnant women to avoid paracetamol, also known as acetaminophen or Tylenol.
The review aimed to provide reliable information for prospective mothers and their doctors.
The study's findings contradict previous concerns about the painkiller's potential impact.

clusters.title: It pays to support women’s health in the workplace | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Workplace support for women's health is beneficial

items.title: It pays to support women’s health in the workplace | Letter
items.standfirst: Prof Geeta Nargund says employers need to take action on health inequality as research shows more than 32% of women aren’t receiving enough help to stay in workThe Keep Britain Working review has shed valuable light on the number of working-age adults in the UK falling out of work due to ill health (Fixing Britain’s worklessness crisis will cost employers £6bn a year, report says, 5 November). As part of this, we should also specifically acknowledge the impact of women’s health issues and the role of employers in addressing these.In a report by the NHS Confederation in partnership with our foundation, we found that an estimated £11bn is lost annually due to absenteeism for gynaecological conditions alone. And earlier this year, our research found that 15% of women report having to change to part-time work and 14% have had to quit work due to women’s health conditions. Furthermore, 32% of women reported that they aren’t receiving enough support for their health issues from their employers. Continue reading...
items.content: Prof Geeta Nargund says employers need to take action on health inequality as research shows more than 32% of women aren’t receiving enough help to stay in workThe Keep Britain Working review has shed valuable light on the number of working-age adults in the UK falling out of work due to ill health (Fixing Britain’s worklessness crisis will cost employers £6bn a year, report says, 5 November). As part of this, we should also specifically acknowledge the impact of women’s health issues and the role of employers in addressing these.In a report by the NHS Confederation in partnership with our foundation, we found that an estimated £11bn is lost annually due to absenteeism for gynaecological conditions alone. And earlier this year, our research found that 15% of women report having to change to part-time work and 14% have had to quit work due to women’s health conditions. Furthermore, 32% of women reported that they aren’t receiving enough support for their health issues from their employers. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Research shows over 32% of women lack sufficient workplace health support.
A report estimates £11 billion in annual losses due to gynecological conditions.
15% of women have switched to part-time work due to health issues.
14% of women have quit jobs because of women's health conditions.
Employers need to address health inequality to support women's well-being.

clusters.title: Older people playing pickleball isn’t risky – it’s medicine | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Pickleball is beneficial for older people's health

items.title: Older people playing pickleball isn’t risky – it’s medicine | Letter
items.standfirst: I’d rather see active, smiling people with the odd strain than a generation glued to the sofa, says physiotherapist Christien BirdSo what if a 2020 study found that 91% of pickleball injuries involved people aged over 50 (You should act your age – at least when it comes to exercise. Here’s why, 3 November)? Most pickleball players are over 50! I’d rather see active, smiling people with the odd strain than a generation glued to the sofa. The real health crisis isn’t overexercising – it’s inactivity.Fitness is the biggest predictor of long-term health and independence. Ageing is inevitable, but fragility is not. Women in particular face an accelerated loss of bone and muscle through menopause, yet 84% of inactive women going through menopause want to be more active and 90% would get active if advised by a professional. There is still a societal acceptance that it is OK to be a fragile older lady behind a Zimmer frame with no bum in her trousers. Continue reading...
items.content: I’d rather see active, smiling people with the odd strain than a generation glued to the sofa, says physiotherapist Christien BirdSo what if a 2020 study found that 91% of pickleball injuries involved people aged over 50 (You should act your age – at least when it comes to exercise. Here’s why, 3 November)? Most pickleball players are over 50! I’d rather see active, smiling people with the odd strain than a generation glued to the sofa. The real health crisis isn’t overexercising – it’s inactivity.Fitness is the biggest predictor of long-term health and independence. Ageing is inevitable, but fragility is not. Women in particular face an accelerated loss of bone and muscle through menopause, yet 84% of inactive women going through menopause want to be more active and 90% would get active if advised by a professional. There is still a societal acceptance that it is OK to be a fragile older lady behind a Zimmer frame with no bum in her trousers. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A physiotherapist argues pickleball is beneficial for older adults' health.
The author prefers active people with strains over a sedentary generation.
Fitness is a key predictor of long-term health and independence.
84% of inactive menopausal women want to be more active.
The article challenges societal acceptance of fragility in older women.

clusters.title: She left her desk job and walked 3,541 miles from Mexico to Canada: ‘Give yourself permission’
clusters.neutral_headline: Woman hikes 3,541 miles from Mexico to Canada

items.title: She left her desk job and walked 3,541 miles from Mexico to Canada: ‘Give yourself permission’
items.standfirst: Jessica Guo hiked 30 miles a day, becoming the first woman to continuously hike two historic US trails in a calendar yearJessica Guo had only slept for two-and-a-half hours on an overnight bus when she arrived at the Mexico-US border near Lordsburg, New Mexico, in April. Out of the window she saw a flat, shadeless landscape. First-day jitters had Guo questioning what she was doing there.The former consultant had left corporate America to attempt something no woman had completed: a single, continuous hike of the Continental Divide Trail (CDT) and the Great Divide Trail (GDT) in one calendar year. Continue reading...

Out of the window she saw a flat, shadeless landscape. First-day jitters had Guo questioning what she was doing there.The former consultant had left corporate America to attempt something no woman had completed: a single, continuous hike of the Continental Divide Trail (CDT) and the Great Divide Trail (GDT) in one calendar year. Continue reading...

Guo left her desk job to undertake the challenging hiking endeavor.
She started her journey at the Mexico-US border near Lordsburg, New Mexico.
Guo's achievement involved a continuous hike within one calendar year.

clusters.title: What we lose when we surrender care to algorithms | Eric Reinhart
clusters.neutral_headline: Algorithms in healthcare raise societal concerns

items.title: What we lose when we surrender care to algorithms | Eric Reinhart
items.standfirst: A dangerous faith in AI is sweeping American healthcare – with consequences for the basis of society itselfThe computer interrupted while Pamela was still speaking. I had accompanied her – my dear friend – to a recent doctor’s appointment. She is in her 70s, lives alone while navigating multiple chronic health issues, and has been getting short of breath climbing the front stairs to her apartment. In the exam room, she spoke slowly and self-consciously, the way people often do when they are trying to describe their bodies and anxieties to strangers. Midway through her description of how she had been feeling, the doctor clicked his mouse and a block of text began to bloom across the computer monitor.The clinic had adopted an artificial-intelligence scribe, and it was transcribing and summarizing the conversation in real time. It was also highlighting keywords, suggesting diagnostic possibilities and providing billing codes. The doctor, apparently satisfied that his computer had captured an adequate description of Pamela’s chief complaint and symptoms, turned away from us and began reviewing the text on the screen as Pamela kept speaking. Continue reading...
items.content: A dangerous faith in AI is sweeping American healthcare – with consequences for the basis of society itselfThe computer interrupted while Pamela was still speaking. I had accompanied her – my dear friend – to a recent doctor’s appointment. She is in her 70s, lives alone while navigating multiple chronic health issues, and has been getting short of breath climbing the front stairs to her apartment. In the exam room, she spoke slowly and self-consciously, the way people often do when they are trying to describe their bodies and anxieties to strangers. Midway through her description of how she had been feeling, the doctor clicked his mouse and a block of text began to bloom across the computer monitor.The clinic had adopted an artificial-intelligence scribe, and it was transcribing and summarizing the conversation in real time. It was also highlighting keywords, suggesting diagnostic possibilities and providing billing codes. The doctor, apparently satisfied that his computer had captured an adequate description of Pamela’s chief complaint and symptoms, turned away from us and began reviewing the text on the screen as Pamela kept speaking. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the impact of AI in American healthcare.
An AI scribe was used during a doctor's appointment with an elderly patient.
The AI transcribed, summarized, and suggested diagnoses in real time.
The author questions the reliance on AI in medical consultations.
The article raises concerns about the future of human interaction in healthcare.

clusters.title: If you’re feeling anxious, take a moment to pause before pouring that glass of wine | Diane Young
clusters.neutral_headline: Anxiety can lead to harmful coping behaviors

items.title: If you’re feeling anxious, take a moment to pause before pouring that glass of wine | Diane Young
items.standfirst: Anxiety can disrupt relationships, affect sleep and lead to harmful coping behaviours. Early awareness is crucialThe modern mind is a column where experts discuss mental health issues they are seeing in their workWhen Mia*, 35, walks into my office, she looks composed and ready to start her day fresh with a counselling session. But having seen Mia for almost half a year now, I know she masks the truth behind her polished facade, and I notice the subtle tension in her shoulders that gives it away.Mia tells me that the night before, she had poured herself “just one glass of wine” to unwind after a long day. One glass became two, then three. It’s a pattern she has grown used to; a quiet ritual that helps her “switch off” from the racing thoughts that flood her mind when the day finally slows down. Continue reading...
items.content: Anxiety can disrupt relationships, affect sleep and lead to harmful coping behaviours. Early awareness is crucialThe modern mind is a column where experts discuss mental health issues they are seeing in their workWhen Mia*, 35, walks into my office, she looks composed and ready to start her day fresh with a counselling session. But having seen Mia for almost half a year now, I know she masks the truth behind her polished facade, and I notice the subtle tension in her shoulders that gives it away.Mia tells me that the night before, she had poured herself “just one glass of wine” to unwind after a long day. One glass became two, then three. It’s a pattern she has grown used to; a quiet ritual that helps her “switch off” from the racing thoughts that flood her mind when the day finally slows down. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the link between anxiety and alcohol consumption.
A woman uses alcohol to cope with racing thoughts and anxiety.
The author highlights the potential for alcohol to worsen anxiety.
Early awareness of anxiety is crucial for managing the condition.
The article explores the impact of anxiety on relationships and sleep.

clusters.title: California’s drying Salton Sea harms the lungs of people living nearby, say researchers
clusters.neutral_headline: Drying Salton Sea harms lungs of nearby residents

items.title: California’s drying Salton Sea harms the lungs of people living nearby, say researchers
items.standfirst: Experts suspect that dust from the sea contains endotoxic bacteria membranes caused by fertilizer runoffChemical-laden dust from southern California’s drying Salton Sea is likely harming the lungs of people around the shrinking body of water, and the effects are especially pronounced in children, new peer-reviewed research from the University of California, Irvine, shows.A separate peer-reviewed study from the University of California, Riverside, also found the Salton Sea’s contaminated dust seemed to alter lung microbiome, which could trigger pulmonary issues that have been reported around the lake. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts suspect that dust from the sea contains endotoxic bacteria membranes caused by fertilizer runoffChemical-laden dust from southern California’s drying Salton Sea is likely harming the lungs of people around the shrinking body of water, and the effects are especially pronounced in children, new peer-reviewed research from the University of California, Irvine, shows.A separate peer-reviewed study from the University of California, Riverside, also found the Salton Sea’s contaminated dust seemed to alter lung microbiome, which could trigger pulmonary issues that have been reported around the lake. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Dust from the Salton Sea is likely harming the lungs of nearby residents.
The effects are especially pronounced in children, according to research.
The dust contains endotoxic bacteria membranes from fertilizer runoff.
A study found the dust alters the lung microbiome.
This could trigger pulmonary issues reported around the lake.

clusters.neutral_headline: UK red kites aid Spanish cousins

items.title: Back from the brink: UK red kites aid Spanish cousins
items.standfirst: A project to revive red kite populations in south-west Spain sees new mating pairs and chicks.
items.content: A project to revive red kite populations in south-west Spain sees new mating pairs and chicks.

ai_summary: A project is reviving red kite populations in south-west Spain.
The project has resulted in new mating pairs and chicks.
The initiative aims to boost the red kite population.
The article highlights the success of the conservation efforts.
The focus is on the positive impact of the project.

clusters.title: ‘They treat men like vending machines’: inside the hidden world of social media sperm selling
clusters.neutral_headline: Social media sperm selling is a hidden world

items.title: ‘They treat men like vending machines’: inside the hidden world of social media sperm selling
items.standfirst: Parenthood can seem an impossible dream for many, and online sperm donor groups offer a solution, but they can be a murky world A man going by the name “Rod Kissme” claims to have “very strong sperm”. It may seem like an eccentric boast for a Facebook profile page, but then this is no mundane corner of the internet. The group where Rod and other men advertise themselves is a community where women and couples come, in many cases, to fulfil a lifelong dream: parenthood.There is a growing number of online sperm donor groups on social media. They offer people the chance of parenting children in an unregulated, dangerous but surprisingly straightforward way. Continue reading...
items.content: Parenthood can seem an impossible dream for many, and online sperm donor groups offer a solution, but they can be a murky world A man going by the name “Rod Kissme” claims to have “very strong sperm”. It may seem like an eccentric boast for a Facebook profile page, but then this is no mundane corner of the internet. The group where Rod and other men advertise themselves is a community where women and couples come, in many cases, to fulfil a lifelong dream: parenthood.There is a growing number of online sperm donor groups on social media. They offer people the chance of parenting children in an unregulated, dangerous but surprisingly straightforward way. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Online sperm donor groups offer a solution for parenthood.
These groups operate in an unregulated and potentially dangerous way.
A man named "Rod Kissme" advertises his sperm on social media.
The article explores the murky world of online sperm donation.
The groups offer a straightforward way for people to have children.
